key_insight: A single panoramic metric-depth foundation model trained on a large, mixed dataset (real, high‑quality synthetic, and text‑to‑image panoramas) plus a three‑stage pseudo‑labeling strategy generalizes across diverse scene distances and reduces indoor/outdoor and synthetic/real domain gaps.
problem_solved: How to obtain reliable metric depth from panoramic images across wide distance ranges and varied domains given limited dense ground truth and large domain shifts between indoor/outdoor and synthetic/real data.
method: Construct a large-scale, heterogeneous panorama dataset by merging public benchmarks, UE5 high-fidelity synthetic scenes, text-to-image generated panoramas, and web-collected real panoramas.
Apply a three-stage pseudo-labeling / curriculum training pipeline to progressively produce and refine metric depth supervision that bridges indoor/outdoor and synthetic/real gaps.
Design a panorama-aware training framework with metric-consistent objectives (multi-scale supervision and distance-aware losses) to produce a foundation model that generalizes across scene distances.
impact: Delivers a robust, general-purpose panoramic depth model that lowers dependence on dense ground truth and improves depth prediction across near and far ranges—useful for robotics, AR/VR, autonomous navigation, and large-scale scene understanding.
visual_elements: Dataset composition pie chart (public vs UE5 synthetic vs text-to-image vs web real)

paper_title: Depth Any Panoramas: A Foundation Model for Panoramic Depth Estimation
paper_authors: Xin Lin, Meixi Song, Dizhe Zhang, Wenxuan Lu, Haodong Li
